post_text: Help us welcome our new staff to Spartan Country. Let us introduce you to Nikki Kane. Mrs. Kane is a counselor at the High School. Mrs. Kane, a Maine-Endwell grad, looks forward to being a part of the Spartan community and working with her bright and compelling students. Her message to her students: “Facing a new school year full of so many unknowns, just remember that we will be here by your side, in the thick of it, every step of the way! As best said by Brene Brown, ‘This pandemic experience is a massive experiment in collective vulnerability. We can be our worst selves when we’re afraid, or our very best, bravest selves. In the context of fear and vulnerability, there is often very little in between because when we are uncertain and afraid our default is self-protection. We don’t have to be scary when we’re scared. Let’s choose awkward, brave, and kind. And let’s choose each other.’”

Work on the district’s solar project has begun! The solar field will be constructed on district-owned vacant land adjacent to Maine Memorial Elementary School.
Preparation for the array installation will take place now through the rest of June.
Please note that the stone parking lot near the Maine Memorial playground will not be accessible until further notice.
Array construction begins in July. Permanent fencing will be installed in August, followed by array and mechanical completion (August) and transformer completion (September).
Residents authorized the district to purchase the 34 acres that will be the location of the array field in a capital project referendum in 2007. It has remained undeveloped since. At their Sept. 12, 2019 meeting, the district’s Board of Education entered into a predevelopment agreement with Renovus Energy.

Isabelle Bordages is just a freshman, but she has deep roots in the struggle for water equity in another part of the world. Isabelle drew on her grandmother’s experience growing up in Egypt for her accepted presentation into the World Food Prize New York Institute Program. The event previously set for March 27 at Cornell University, was held virtually on May 27.
Isabelle presented her paper, “Egypt: The Thirst for Water”, at the event, which brings high school students together with local leaders and experts on critical global challenges.
For her project, Isabelle explored the issue of water scarcity in Egypt. Drawing on her conversations with her grandmother and additional research, she summarized the problem and discussed typical family life and conditions of life in the community, providing a detailed description of how she believes this specific issue could be resolved, as well has her interest in the topic.
You can read more about Isabelle's accomplishment on the district website: https://www.me.stier.org/protected/ArticleView.aspx?iid=5P00P0&dasi=220

Congratulations to seniors Dominic Passante, Mackenzie Shields and Cole Tinklepaugh on achieving the New York State Seal of Biliteracy (NYSSB)! The students are recognized for their proficiency in French. Jon Gerlach is the students’ HS French teacher.
The NYSSB recognizes high school graduates who have attained a high level of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in one or more languages, in addition to English. On April 29, Dominic, Mackenzie and Cole made presentations that demonstrated their language skills to a panel of judges fluent in French. The NYSSB will be affixed to the students’ diploma and transcript.
This is a very prestigious award and very difficult to attain. Many hours of outside preparation and studying go into achieving the NYSSB. The students and their teacher do this voluntarily, it is not associated with a class.
Way to go Spartans!

We asked, you responded, we listened. The Board of Education at their April 30 meeting voted not to exceed the allowable tax levy limit of 1.94% for the 2020-21 school year. The board made their decision after reviewing the results of a district-wide survey. The survey received 1100 responses and over 300 comments.
While the board appreciates the support of residents to support a higher tax levy, based on survey results and additional comments from residents, the board recognizes that this is not the right time to exceed the tax levy limit.
Thank you to all the residents who took the time to complete the survey. We value our community and we appreciate your continued support as we strive to deliver a premier education to each Maine-Endwell student.
The full presentation to the BOE on the survey results is posted on the district website.

Congratulations Spartans! Homer Brink and the High School have been recognized as high achieving and high progress Recognition Schools by the New York State Education Department. Under the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) plan, Recognition Schools are those with high academic achievement and strong progress, that also perform acceptably for all subgroups for which they are accountable.
To receive Recognition School status, schools must:
Have an accountability status of Good Standing;
Have a Level 4 for the Combined Composite Performance and Growth indicator for elementary and middle schools or a Level 4 for the Combined Composite Performance and Graduation Rate for high schools for the All Students group.
Schools must also meet accountability indicators in several areas including ELA and math progress, absenteeism, college, career and civic readiness.

Congratulations to these High School artists who recently won awards in the Broome County Emerging Artist Competition sponsored by the Fine Arts Society of the Southern Tier (FASST) and the Broome County Arts Council.
Brynn Hempstead took first place for her illustration in the Broome County Arts Council BCAC Beethoven Project. This category, in conjunction with the Binghamton Philharmonic, celebrates the life and times of Beethoven.
Receiving honorable mention in the art competition are Noah Cole for his painting, and McKenna Seavey for her drawing.
The contest was judged by local artists and featured art from students in eight schools.
Congratulations Spartans!

The good news continues...
Congratulations to the M-E music department and musicians, and Spartan Country, on being named a 2020 Best Communities for Music Education by the NAMM Foundation. Maine-Endwell was selected for the honor based on an application process and data about funding, staffing, commitment to standards and access to music instruction.

post_text: Students in Rachel Murat's AP Government and Politics class welcomed a special guest to their virtual classroom today, Congressman Anthony Brindisi. Using the video conferencing service ZOOM, Representative Brindisi was able to have a face-to-face meeting with students. He spoke about his path into politics and then answered student questions. Topics primarily centered around the effects of COVID-19 on the upcoming primary and general elections, the federal government's economic stimulus package as it relates to student loan debt and small businesses, as well as the federal response to the need for medical supplies and equipment. Thank you Representative Brindisi for taking time out of your schedule to meet with our Spartans!
